Article Body

Thao Uyen Chau

Art 104

Professor Holberton

Final Project Draft

Abstract

Keywords

VR, Metaverse, Art Marketplace, Web 3.0, Energy Waste

Discipline List

Philosophy of Mind; Theatre and Performance Studies; Digital Communications and Networking; Economics;

  1. Intro
    The idea of creating a parallel world that replicates extends, or enhances the current physical world has been a dream of many people. Starting in the 1990s, the dream slowly became reality, but one that was more virtual than real. Virtual Reality (VR) is the parallel world that exists in software programs and computer hardware. The Switch journal interviewed leading thinkers of VR, Brenda Laurel and Linda Jacobson, to discuss and contextualize VR development and its implication for society and art. After thirty years, Virtual Reality has taken shape to form the foundation of the Metaverse, realizing concepts and ideas from the early days of VR but also introducing negative aspects that need to be addressed.
    Laurel and Jacobson are some of the early adopters and thinkers of VR who deliberated concepts that are still influential today. One core application of VR is to allow the user to experience the virtual world from different perspectives, ranging from animals to different people or different gender. The capability to experience different perspectives in VR may allow the mind to be disembodied from the physical body. However, Laurel appreciates the idea of having perspectives grounded in the physical body even with the advent of VR medium. Laurel states, “Any medium that further weakens my sense of physical existence, right now, in real-time, weakens my political power and political will to take care of myself.”[1] Laurel believes that separating the mind from the body weakens the self and reduces political power and political will. Rather than use VR as a tool for disembodiment, it can be used to facilitate interactions between users and the environment. Jacobson states, “It’s important to me that VR attain its lofty status as an artist’s tool, an artistic medium, one that will allow the viewer or participant to become co-creator in the art. That alone affects our self-identity. With VR you’re no longer just a consumer.”[2] Jacobson believes that the strength of VR is to give users agency and the power to make decisions and creative works, rather than just being a simple participant or consumer.
  1. Body

    a. Metaverse is a virtual shared space that incorporates VR, augmented reality, and the internet.

    b. More advanced development of VR

    c. Features and functionality
    Metaverse will become a place where people from all over the world can meet up, play, create, and trade.
    d. The negative side of Metaverse
    Abuse and harassment
    Environmental: energy and e-waste
    There are reports about virtual abuse and harassment in the Metaverse. This will be a difficult issue that Metaverse creators need to figure out how to resolve to create a safe virtual environment, which has always been a challenge for virtual environments. Also, people can over use the space which could lead to overconsumption and waste of energy.
    e. Examples of Art in Metaverse
    Dancing in Metaverse
    Grand Theft Auto Online or Substrata
    These two examples are what people are experimenting in the Metaverse, and what can be created in space.

  1. Conclusion
    Promise and opportunity of Metaverse
    Link how art can enrich this world and now is the time to create in this new medium
    Metaverse is a future that humanity will have to embrace despite hesitations and concerns about whether it is an essential and beneficial development to society. Therefore, it is a good time to perform more research to inform people about the pros and cons of the new creation which can have a great effect on us
